metadata.synopsis: The residents of a rural mining town discover that an unfortunate chemical spill has caused hundreds of little spiders to mutate overnight to the size of SUVs. It's up to mining engineer Chris McCormack (David Arquette) and Sheriff Sam Parker (Kari Wuhrer) to mobilize an eclectic group of townspeople into battle against the bloodthirsty eight-legged beasts.

reviews: The computer graphics are much more convincing than in comparative killer animal movies, advancing in realism just enough not to be a complete distraction.
The plot is predictable, the characters are never fleshed out...
What it lacks in scares, however, Eight Legged Freaks makes up for with gallons of gooey-green spider guts.
A fun, fantastic homage to the B movies of the golden age of horror cinema...
The best giant-spider movie I've seen in quite some time.
There's something distasteful about a supposed 'B-movie' made with the financial backing of a major Hollywood studio and production company.
Fans of the Kevin Bacon action-comedy Tremors (1989) will feel right at home.
If you want to enjoy a campy but fun B-movie, then go with a real B-film . . . Don't fall for mainstream Hollywood's pale big-budget imitation.
Isn't it worth paying into any film that features a talking parrot writing off The Sixth Sense with just a single line?
While the gigantic spider animation is not bad in this movie, just about everything else is absolutely awful, including the story, the dialogue, and especially the acting.
Fun comedy horror that recognizes its limitations and revels in its own absurdity, though too polite to be a classic in its genre.
